content:
Eric Forgy said:

Hi :wave:

I'm coming back to this stream after putting a lot of elbow grease into:

Bimodules vs Spans

  • Puzzle 1
  • Puzzle 2
  • Puzzle 3

There, we learned that in (Setop,×,∗)(\mathsf{Set^{op}},\times,*)(Setop,×,∗):

  • A monoid object AAA is a set with multiplication given by the diagonal map.
  • An AAA-module XXX is a function X→A.X\to A.X→A.
  • An (A,B)(A,B)(A,B)-module XXX is a span A←X→B.A\leftarrow X\rightarrow B.A←X→B.
  • Tensoring an (A,B)(A,B)(A,B)-bimodule XXX with a (B,C)(B,C)(B,C)-bimodule YYY is an (A,C)(A,C)(A,C)-bimodule X×BYX\times_B YX×B​Y corresponding to the composition of the respective spans

Good morning :coffee:

I'm still trying to pull all this together.

I'll try to explain / generalize what I learned in my words to see If I understand.

Given a monoidal category (C,⊗,1)(C,\otimes,1)(C,⊗,1):

  • Every object in CCC is a monoid object in (Cop,⊗,1).(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes, 1).(Cop,⊗,1).
  • Every span R←M→SR\leftarrow M\rightarrow SR←M→S in CCC is an (R,S)(R,S)(R,S)-bimodule in (Cop,⊗,1).(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes, 1).(Cop,⊗,1).

Since every morphism f:M→Sf:M\to Sf:M→S is equivalent to a span
{}
M←1M→fS,M\overset{1}{\leftarrow}M\overset{f}{\rightarrow} S,M←1M→fS,
{}
this also implies:

  • Every morphism f:M→Sf:M\to Sf:M→S in CCC is a left SSS-module in (Cop,⊗,1).(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes, 1).(Cop,⊗,1).

Right modules are a little trickier.

  • Every span R←M→1MR\leftarrow M\overset{1}{\rightarrow} MR←M→1M is a right RRR-module in (Cop,⊗,1).(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes, 1).(Cop,⊗,1).

This reminds of a cool tidbit:

  • A category internal to some category CCC is the same as a monad in Span(C).\mathsf{Span}(C).Span(C).

from https://www.math.uni-hamburg.de/home/schreiber/SpanMod.pdf.

I don't know if this is great notation, but I think it means:
{}
Span(C,⊗,1)≅Bim(Cop,⊗,1).\mathsf{Span}(C,\otimes,1) \cong \mathsf{Bim}(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes,1).Span(C,⊗,1)≅Bim(Cop,⊗,1).

I am probably spewing nonsense at this point, but that makes me think:
{}
Cospan(C,⊗,1)≅Bim(C,⊗,1).\mathsf{Cospan}(C,\otimes,1) \cong \mathsf{Bim}(C,\otimes,1).Cospan(C,⊗,1)≅Bim(C,⊗,1).
That actually makes a LOT of sense to me, but if it was true, I'd think I would have seen it in the 10s of papers I've been skimming the last couple of weeks.
I think it should be correct though :thinking:

I think the puzzles show
{}
Span(Set,×,∗)≅Bim(Setop,×,∗).\mathsf{Span(Set},\times,*)\cong \mathsf{Bim(Set^{op}},\times,*).Span(Set,×,∗)≅Bim(Setop,×,∗).

If
{}
Cospan(C,⊗,1)≅Bim(C,⊗,1),\mathsf{Cospan}(C,\otimes,1) \cong \mathsf{Bim}(C,\otimes,1),Cospan(C,⊗,1)≅Bim(C,⊗,1),
{}
it would be a good exercise to show
{}
Cospan(Set,×,∗)≅Bim(Set,×,∗).\mathsf{Cospan(Set},\times,) \cong \mathsf{Bim(Set},\times,).Cospan(Set,×,∗)≅Bim(Set,×,∗).
{}
That might be within my grasp :sweat_smile:
I'm starting to see how this all ties together (I think) :blush:

Btw, I can hear John's voice in my head, so let me explain what I mean by Bim(C,⊗,1)\mathsf{Bim}(C,\otimes,1)Bim(C,⊗,1) :sweat_smile:

The (C,⊗,1)(C,\otimes,1)(C,⊗,1) part just means a monoidal category.

Bim(C,⊗,1)\mathsf{Bim}(C,\otimes,1)Bim(C,⊗,1) is a bicategory whose

  • Objects are monoid objects in (C,⊗,1)(C,\otimes,1)(C,⊗,1)
  • Morphisms are (R,S)(R,S)(R,S)-bimodules in (C,⊗,1)(C,\otimes,1)(C,⊗,1)
  • 2-morphisms are bimodule homomorphisms

Similarly, Cospan(C,⊗,1)\mathsf{Cospan}(C,\otimes,1)Cospan(C,⊗,1) is a bicategory whose

  • Objects are monoid objects in (C,⊗,1)(C,\otimes,1)(C,⊗,1)
  • Morphisms are cospans R→M←SR\rightarrow M\leftarrow SR→M←S in (C,⊗,1)(C,\otimes,1)(C,⊗,1)
  • 2-morphisms are the usual maps between cospans

It is easy to see that
{}
Cospan(Cop,⊗,1)≅Bim(Cop,⊗,1)\sout{\mathsf{Cospan}(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes,1) \cong \mathsf{Bim}(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes,1)}Cospan(Cop,⊗,1)≅Bim(Cop,⊗,1)​
{}
because every object of (C,⊗,1)\sout{(C,\otimes,1)}(C,⊗,1)​ is a monoid object in (Cop,⊗,1),\sout{(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes,1),}(Cop,⊗,1),​ but that should also mean
{}
Cospan(C,⊗,1)≅Bim(C,⊗,1)\sout{\mathsf{Cospan}(C,\otimes,1) \cong \mathsf{Bim}(C,\otimes,1)}Cospan(C,⊗,1)≅Bim(C,⊗,1)​
{}
more generally.

This ties in with my other stuff because a functor
{}
N→Span(Set)\mathbb{N}\to\mathsf{Span(Set)}N→Span(Set)
{}
picks out a monoid object in Span(Set)\mathsf{Span(Set)}Span(Set) and
{}
[N,Span(Set)][\mathbb{N},\mathsf{Span(Set)}][N,Span(Set)]
{}
is a category of monoid objects in Span(Set).\mathsf{Span(Set)}.Span(Set).
{}
More generally,
{}
[N,C][\mathbb{N},C][N,C]
{}
is a category of monoid objects in C.C.C.
{}
(I think)

It would be pretty cool if
{}
[N,Span(Set)]≅Span([N,Set],×,∗).[\mathbb{N},\mathsf{Span(Set)}] \cong \mathsf{Span}([\mathbb{N},\mathsf{Set}],\times,*).[N,Span(Set)]≅Span([N,Set],×,∗).

Eric Forgy said:

Good morning :coffee:

I'm still trying to pull all this together.

I'll try to explain / generalize what I learned in my words to see If I understand.

Given a monoidal category (C,⊗,1)(C,\otimes,1)(C,⊗,1):

  • Every object in CCC is a monoid object in (Cop,⊗,1).(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes, 1).(Cop,⊗,1).

No! If you prove this for (C,⊗,1)=(Set,×,∗)(C,\otimes,1) = (\mathsf{Set}, \times, \ast)(C,⊗,1)=(Set,×,∗) you'll see what special features of this example are being used. You should really do this, since it's not hard, it's enlightening, and it lets you prove a more general result. I sketched the key steps earlier. The proof does not work for all monoidal categories.

The last part actually obvious: since every monoidal category is the opposite of its opposite, if every object in the opposite of every monoidal category were a monoid object, then every object in every monoidal category would be a monoid object!

And by the way, the result for C=SetC = \mathsf{Set}C=Set is actually much better than what you just stated:

Theorem. Every object of (Setop,×,∗)(\mathsf{Set}^{\text{op}}, \times, \ast)(Setop,×,∗) is a monoid object in a unique way. This way makes it a commutative monoid. Making every object into a monoid object in this way, every morphism in (Setop,×,∗)(\mathsf{Set}^{\text{op}}, \times, \ast)(Setop,×,∗) is a homomorphism of monoid objects.
And... I just had this open https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/Eckmann-Hilton+argument :sweat_smile:

Eric Forgy said:

This ties in with my other stuff because a functor
{}
N→Span(Set)\mathbb{N}\to\mathsf{Span(Set)}N→Span(Set)
{}
picks out a monoid object in Span(Set)\mathsf{Span(Set)}Span(Set) and
{}
[N,Span(Set)][\mathbb{N},\mathsf{Span(Set)}][N,Span(Set)]
{}
is a category of monoid objects in Span(Set).\mathsf{Span(Set)}.Span(Set).

I don't think that's true. But maybe you're using words in a somewhat different way than I do. For example, you are thinking of N\mathbb{N}N as a category somehow, but there are at least two really famous ways to do this, and you're not saying which one you're using. However, I don't think your claims are true in either interpretation.

Maybe I'm wrong.

If you try to prove your claim here, we'll see what's going on.

So is the correct way to generalize what we learned in your puzzles to generalize to commutative monoidal categories? Is this true:

Given a commutative monoidal category (C,⊗,1)(C,\otimes,1)(C,⊗,1):

  • Every object in CCC is a monoid object in (Cop,⊗,1).(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes, 1).(Cop,⊗,1).
  • Every span R←M→SR\leftarrow M\rightarrow SR←M→S in CCC is an (R,S)(R,S)(R,S)-bimodule in (Cop,⊗,1).(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes, 1).(Cop,⊗,1).
Hopefully something good can be salvaged from this mess I created :sweat_smile:

I need to refine N\mathbb{N}N because I am taking your advice and going to treat Span(Set)\mathsf{Span(Set)}Span(Set) as a bicategory rather than a category with isomorphism classes. I'm guessing it will involve 111 as a monad somehow.

I don't know if this is the right N\mathbb{N}N, but it is kind of neat.

Let N\mathbb{N}N denote the bicategory with

  • One object ∙.\bullet.∙.
  • Morphisms are spans ∙←m∙→m∙,\bullet\overset{m}{\leftarrow}\bullet\overset{m}{\rightarrow}\bullet,∙←m∙→m∙, where mmm is a natural number.
  • 2-morphisms are maps between spans (∙←m1∙→m1∙)⇒m(∙←m2∙→m2∙)(\bullet\overset{m_1}{\leftarrow}\bullet\overset{m_1}{\rightarrow}\bullet)\overset{m}{\Rightarrow}(\bullet\overset{m_2}{\leftarrow}\bullet\overset{m_2}{\rightarrow}\bullet)(∙←m1​∙→m1​∙)⇒m(∙←m2​∙→m2​∙) where mmm is a natural number and m1=m+m2.m_1 = m + m_2.m1​=m+m2​.
Composition of spans
2-morphism

Eric Forgy said:

So is the correct way to generalize what we learned in your puzzles to generalize to commutative monoidal categories? Is this true:

Given a commutative monoidal category (C,⊗,1)(C,\otimes,1)(C,⊗,1):

  • Every object in CCC is a monoid object in (Cop,⊗,1).(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes, 1).(Cop,⊗,1).
  • Every span R←M→SR\leftarrow M\rightarrow SR←M→S in CCC is an (R,S)(R,S)(R,S)-bimodule in (Cop,⊗,1).(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes, 1).(Cop,⊗,1).

No. I already said that the first one is false - see below for my explanation of why it's false. Did I write that all for nothing?

The second is false too.

For example, they're both false when (Cop,⊗,1)=(Set,×,1)(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes, 1) = (\mathsf{Set}, \times, 1)(Cop,⊗,1)=(Set,×,1). That's easy to show, and you should show it.

John Baez said:

Eric Forgy said:

Good morning :coffee:

I'm still trying to pull all this together.

I'll try to explain / generalize what I learned in my words to see If I understand.

Given a monoidal category (C,⊗,1)(C,\otimes,1)(C,⊗,1):

  • Every object in CCC is a monoid object in (Cop,⊗,1).(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes, 1).(Cop,⊗,1).

No! If you prove this for (C,⊗,1)=(Set,×,∗)(C,\otimes,1) = (\mathsf{Set}, \times, \ast)(C,⊗,1)=(Set,×,∗) you'll see what special features of this example are being used. You should really do this, since it's not hard, it's enlightening, and it lets you prove a more general result. I sketched the key steps earlier.

The proof does not work for all monoidal categories. This is actually obvious: since every monoidal category is the opposite of its opposite, if every object in the opposite of every monoidal category were a monoid object, then every object in every monoidal category would be a monoid object!

And by the way, the result for C=SetC = \mathsf{Set}C=Set is actually much better than what you just stated:

Theorem. Every object of (Setop,×,∗)(\mathsf{Set}^{\text{op}}, \times, \ast)(Setop,×,∗) is a monoid object in a unique way. This way makes it a commutative monoid. Making every object into a monoid object in this way, every morphism in (Setop,×,∗)(\mathsf{Set}^{\text{op}}, \times, \ast)(Setop,×,∗) is a homomorphism of monoid objects.

John Baez said:

Eric Forgy said:

So is the correct way to generalize what we learned in your puzzles to generalize to commutative monoidal categories? Is this true:

Given a commutative monoidal category (C,⊗,1)(C,\otimes,1)(C,⊗,1):

  • Every object in CCC is a monoid object in (Cop,⊗,1).(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes, 1).(Cop,⊗,1).
  • Every span R←M→SR\leftarrow M\rightarrow SR←M→S in CCC is an (R,S)(R,S)(R,S)-bimodule in (Cop,⊗,1).(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes, 1).(Cop,⊗,1).

No. I already said that the first one is false - see below for my explanation of why it's false. Did I write that all for nothing?

This is different than what I had before because I was restricting to "commutative" monoidal categories. I didn't ignore what you said. I thought I was incorporating it :thinking:
I was thinking a monoid in a commutative monoidal category should be a commutative monoid.

Oh, okay, I see that's a different guess. It's still false though. You didn't do what I told you to: prove that result is true for (C,⊗,1)=(Set,×,1)(C, \otimes, 1) = (\mathsf{Set}, \times , 1)(C,⊗,1)=(Set,×,1) and see what you are using about the category Set\mathsf{Set}Set that makes the argument work.

Instead, I guess you added one extra assumption and hoped that would be enough. That's a slow way to make progress: make guesses and let me knock them down. It's sort of like throwing darts blindfolded and hoping one hits the target.

I could of course just tell you what's true, but I think it's better if you go through the argument for (C,⊗,1)=(Set,×,1)(C, \otimes, 1) = (\mathsf{Set}, \times , 1)(C,⊗,1)=(Set,×,1) and see what's really going on. You'll see some very special features of this case are being used.

OK. I will work through it. Sorry. I thought I understood it. In the case of Set/Setop,\mathsf{Set/Set^{op}},Set/Setop, we didn't need to think about left / right modules because they are the same in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop which must be related to commutativity somehow. So when you mentioned commutative monoids, I thought that was the answer and moved on to what I considered more pressing issues, but I'll try this proof. Thank you.
Yes, doing that proof was Puzzle 1, and I think it's important!
I did Puzzle 1. I can do it again :sweat_smile:
You may have done it - I'm not really sure - but if so, you didn't analyze what about Set\mathsf{Set}Set you were using. That "analyzing what made the argument work" step is crucial for generalizing.
In Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop, a μ:X×X→X\mu:X\times X\to Xμ:X×X→X corresponds to μop:X→X×X\mu^{op}: X\to X\times Xμop:X→X×X in Set\mathsf{Set}Set which is the diagonal map.

Yes, now you're starting to do the analysis of the argument. If you do it carefully enough, you'll know exactly which sort of categories you can generalize the argument to. And of course you complete this process by proving that the argument generalizes.

The unit η:∗→X\eta: *\to Xη:∗→X in Setop\mathsf{Set^{op}}Setop corresponds to the unique map ηop:X→∗\eta^{op}: X\to *ηop:X→∗ sending every element of XXX to the one element ∙∈∗\bullet\in *∙∈∗ (i.e., ∗*∗ is the terminal set).
Right. So figure out what properties of μop\mu^{\text{op}}μop and ηop\eta^{\text{op}}ηop are required to get a monoid object by this trick.

Associativity:
{}
x↦μop(x,x)↦μop×id((x,x),x)x\overset{\mu^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (x,x)\overset{\mu^\mathsf{op}\times\mathsf{id}}{\mapsto} ((x,x),x)x↦μop​(x,x)↦μop×id​((x,x),x)
{}
x↦μop(x,x)↦id×μop(x,(x,x))↦αop((x,x),x)x\overset{\mu^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (x,x)\overset{\mathsf{id}\times\mu^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (x,(x,x))\overset{\alpha^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto}((x,x),x)x↦μop​(x,x)↦id×μop​(x,(x,x))↦αop​((x,x),x)
{}
Check :check_mark:

Left unit:
{}
x↦μop(x,x)↦ηop×id(∙,x)x\overset{\mu^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (x,x)\overset{\eta^\mathsf{op}\times\mathsf{id}}{\mapsto} (\bullet,x)x↦μop​(x,x)↦ηop×id​(∙,x)
{}
x↦λop(∙,x)x\overset{\lambda^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (\bullet,x)x↦λop​(∙,x)
{}
Check :check_mark:

Right unit:
{}
x↦μop(x,x)↦id×ηop(x,∙)x\overset{\mu^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (x,x)\overset{\mathsf{id}\times\eta^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (x,\bullet)x↦μop​(x,x)↦id×ηop​(x,∙)
{}
x↦ρop(x,∙)x\overset{\rho^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (x,\bullet)x↦ρop​(x,∙)
{}
Check :check_mark:
Confession: I didn't work out left and right units when I did Puzzle 1 and that would have helped with Puzzle 2 :face_palm:

Good! Next, to solve Puzzle 1, you need to show that there's only one way to make any set into a monoid in Setop\mathsf{Set}^{\text{op}}Setop. You've found one way: why is this the only way?

Only after proving that can you confidently claim "a monoid in (Setop,×,1)(\mathsf{Set}^{\text{op}}, \times, 1)(Setop,×,1) is just the same as a set" - no more, no less.

I think I should have started with the most general possibility and widdle it down.

So instead of
{}
μop:x↦(x,x)\mu^{op}: x\mapsto (x,x)μop:x↦(x,x)
{}
I'll look at a more general
{}
μop:x↦(f(x),g(x))\mu^{op}: x\mapsto (f(x),g(x))μop:x↦(f(x),g(x))
{}

Associativity:
{}
x↦μop(f(x),g(x))↦μop×id((f(x),g(x)),g(x))x\overset{\mu^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (f(x),g(x))\overset{\mu^\mathsf{op}\times\mathsf{id}}{\mapsto} ((f(x),g(x)),g(x))x↦μop​(f(x),g(x))↦μop×id​((f(x),g(x)),g(x))
{}
x↦μop(f(x),g(x))↦id×μop(f(x),(f(x),g(x)))↦αop((f(x),f(x)),g(x))x\overset{\mu^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (f(x),g(x))\overset{\mathsf{id}\times\mu^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (f(x),(f(x),g(x)))\overset{\alpha^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto}((f(x),f(x)),g(x))x↦μop​(f(x),g(x))↦id×μop​(f(x),(f(x),g(x)))↦αop​((f(x),f(x)),g(x))

This can only be satisfied if f=gf = gf=g so we've narrowed it down a little.
Right, now you're starting to see the point of this whole puzzle.
By the way, James Dolan gave me this puzzle once and I started just like you did now: with associativity.

Right unit:
{}
x↦μop(f(x),f(x))↦id×ηop(f(x),∙)x\overset{\mu^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (f(x),f(x))\overset{\mathsf{id}\times\eta^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (f(x),\bullet)x↦μop​(f(x),f(x))↦id×ηop​(f(x),∙)
{}
x↦ρop(x,∙).x\overset{\rho^\mathsf{op}}{\mapsto} (x,\bullet).x↦ρop​(x,∙).

This can only be satisfied if f(x)=xf(x) = xf(x)=x, i.e. f=idX.f = \mathsf{id}_X.f=idX​.
Now you're really getting the point.
The humble unit laws are the key here.
Yeah. I did this kind of exercise with James when trying to solve Puzzle 2 and definitely felt my brain muscles growing :muscle:
In fact you didn't even need to use associativity!
If you use both unit laws you see first f=idf = \mathrm{id}f=id and then g=idg = \mathrm{id}g=id.
Cool. Yeah :+1:
Then associativity is free :+1:
I don't know if there's a name for thing that has a multiplication that obeys the unit laws but may not be associative.
But anyway, there's exactly one way to make any set into one of those things in Setop\mathsf{Set}^{\text{op}}Setop.
And then it turns out to be a commutative monoid.
I feel dense, but I'm still missing the punchline :thinking:
It feels a little vacuous, but every set is a comonoid object in Set\mathsf{Set}Set so every set is a monoid in Setop.\mathsf{Set^{op}}.Setop.
You should say in a unique way to get the most for all your hard work.
So now you've solved Puzzle 1.
The next step is to analyze what about the category Set\mathsf{Set}Set made this proof work?
Then you can generalize to certain other categories.
But not all monoidal categories, or even all symmetric monoidal categories.

Eric Forgy said:

It feels a little vacuous, but every set is a comonoid object in Set\mathsf{Set}Set so every set is a monoid in Setop.\mathsf{Set^{op}}.Setop.

:point_of_information: ?
We need monoidal categories where every object is a comonoid object.
That's like saying your result generalizes to categories where the result is true.
Which is true, but scarcely helpful.

John Baez said:

That's like saying your result generalizes to categories where the result is true.

Can't argue with that :joy:
Theorem. This theorem is true for all categories for which this theorem is true.
That's a true theorem.
Right, so I need to get a "little" more specific :sweat_smile:

But all we needed for every set in Set\mathsf{Set}Set to be a comonoid object was a μop\mu^{op}μop, ηop\eta^{op}ηop, λop\lambda^{op}λop and ρop\rho^{op}ρop satisfying left and right unit laws (and associativity, but that probably comes free for any case I'll ever see).
Yes, that's like saying the result is true when it's true.
ηop\eta^{op}ηop, λop\lambda^{op}λop and ρop\rho^{op}ρop all come basically for free.

You have to actually analyze your argument to see what facts about the category of sets you were using. And this may be hard, because you don't have a strong command of the various different properties of categories, so you may not recognize which ones are coming into play.
Oh! One restriction. CCC must have a terminal object?

Well, don't say it must have a terminal object. We're looking for sufficient conditions for the argument to work, not necessary ones. But yeah: you seemed to use something about it having a terminal object.
But more than that, you used the fact that the unit object of your monoidal category is the terminal object!
I guess when you write (C,⊗,1)(C,\otimes,1)(C,⊗,1), the 111 is not always terminal?
You should write III if it's not terminal.
Consider (Vect,⊗,k)(\mathsf{Vect}, \otimes, k)(Vect,⊗,k). The field kkk is not terminal.
Oops. I thought kkk was terminal in Vect\mathsf{Vect}Vect :thinking:
For every V∈Vect,V\in\mathsf{Vect},V∈Vect, I thought we have a dual V∗:V→k.V^*: V\to k.V∗:V→k.
I don't know what that has to do with it or even what it means. Since when is the dual V∗V^\astV∗ a linear map? I thought it was a vector space!
What does it mean for an object to be terminal?
For every object c∈Cc\in Cc∈C, there is a unique morphism c→1.c\to 1.c→1.
Okay, good. So let's look at the category of real vector spaces, where k=Rk = \mathbb{R}k=R. Is R\mathbb{R}R terminal?

Eric Forgy said:

For every V∈Vect,V\in\mathsf{Vect},V∈Vect, I thought we have a dual V∗:V→k.V^*: V\to k.V∗:V→k.

This is a typo. What I meant (which is also wrong) was that any α∈V∗\alpha\in V^*α∈V∗ is a morphism α:V→k\alpha: V\to kα:V→k, but the key is the "unique" part. That often gets me :pensive:
I can think of lots of morphisms V→RV\to\mathbb{R}V→R (which means there is not a unique one).
So kkk is not terminal because for any V∈VectkV\in\mathsf{Vect_k}V∈Vectk​, any two elements α,β∈V∗\alpha,\beta\in V^*α,β∈V∗ are both maps α,β:V→k.\alpha,\beta: V\to k.α,β:V→k.
Or I guess it's not terminal because in general there is more than one linear map from a vector space to the underlying field viewed as a vector space.
Good. So is there a terminal object in Vectk\mathsf{Vect}_kVectk​ or not?

John Baez said:

Good. So is there a terminal object in Vectk\mathsf{Vect}_kVectk​ or not?

Yes! 0
0 is both initial and terminal.

Okay, so (Vectk,⊗,k)(\mathsf{Vect}_k, \otimes , k)(Vectk​,⊗,k) is a nice example of a monoidal category that has a terminal object, but where the terminal object is not the unit object for the tensor product.

Okay. Also, you're writing down a map in terms of an "element" xxx, but for lots of categories the objects don't have "elements".
So no: whoever told you every monoidal category has diagonal maps was lying.

So we have another condition. CCC needs to have diagonal maps.

  • CCC must have diagonal maps.

David Egolf said:

I haven't figured it out yet, but I suspect there's some way of taking the guaranteed Δ\DeltaΔ and "turning it around" so that it becomes the μ\muμ we need.

This is called "op{}^\mathsf{op}op" :blush:

On the one hand, we have μ\muμ in Cop.C^\mathsf{op}.Cop. On the other we have Δ\DeltaΔ in CCC. In what we're talking about μop=Δ.\mu^\mathsf{op} = \Delta.μop=Δ. Put differently, μ\muμ in CopC^\mathsf{op}Cop is the opposite of the diagonal map Δ\DeltaΔ in CCC. That is the definition of μ.\mu.μ.

Summarizing a bit for myself: The key thing is this connection between the monoidal product and the cartesian product. When the monoidal product also enjoys the universal properties of the cartesian product (in some category) then we start getting unique morphisms to it. Unique morphisms to the monoidal product end up inducing a unique way to satisfy the unit laws.

So if a monoidal category (C,⊗,I)(C,\otimes,I)(C,⊗,I) has a diagonal map and a unit that is the terminal object, i.e. I=1I = 1I=1, then every object of CCC is a monoid object in (Cop,⊗,I).(C^\mathsf{op},\otimes,I).(Cop,⊗,I).

BUT... those conditions are precisely the definition of a cartesian monoidal category :blush:

Hence, in a cartesian category (C,×,1)(C,\times,1)(C,×,1), every object of CCC is a monoid object in (Cop,×,1).(C^\mathsf{op},\times,1).(Cop,×,1).
To have a diagonal map, I think you have to have at least binary products, right?

Summarizing a bit for myself: The key thing is this connection between the monoidal product and the cartesian product. When the monoidal product also enjoys the universal properties of the cartesian product (in some category) then we start getting unique morphisms to it. Unique morphisms to the monoidal product end up inducing a unique way to satisfy the unit laws.

No. There are two conditions and they are separate. You need:

  1. Existence of diagonals
  2. The unit element must be terminal
Yeah, I was summarizing the "existence of diagonals" part.
If you have both of those, you have a cartesian category.
The nlab puts it like this: the "monoidal structure is given by the category-theoretic product" in a cartesian category.
As John mentioned, those two conditions amount to the ability to duplicate and delete objects :blush:
I think that condition then implies both conditions 1 and 2

David Egolf said:

The nlab puts it like this: the "monoidal structure is given by the category-theoretic product" in a cartesian category.

This isn't enough. You need to also have I=1.I=1.I=1. John gave a nice counter example. (Vect,×,1)(\mathsf{Vect},\times,1)(Vect,×,1) is a perfectly fine monoidal category with cartesian product, but 1 is not terminal.

[Edit: Sorry.]

So (Vect,×,1)(\mathsf{Vect},\times,1)(Vect,×,1) is not cartesian and vector spaces are not monoid objects in Vectop.\mathsf{Vect^{op}}.Vectop.

[Edit: Sorry.]

I think the monoidal unit can be thought of as the empty monoidal product. If the monoidal product coincides with the cartesian product, then the monoidal unit coincides with the empty cartesian product. We then have an object III so that there is a unique morphism to it from every other object: the monoidal unit must be terminal.

Also note that the nlab suggests that the monoidal unit being terminal is a consequence:
"A cartesian monoidal category (usually just called a cartesian category), is a monoidal category whose monoidal structure is given by the category-theoretic product (and so whose unit is a terminal object)."
It is true that the "empty vector space" is terminal. But it is also initial. When an object is both initial and terminal, it is called a "zero object" 0.
At any rate, this has been fun. I now have a vague intuition for what a monoid in a monoidal category is, and I didn't before.

David Egolf said:

I haven't figured it out yet, but I suspect there's some way of taking the guaranteed Δ\DeltaΔ and "turning it around" so that it becomes the μ\muμ we need.

Yes: If your category C\mathsf{C}C is cartesian, every object xxx in it has a diagonal Δ:x→x×x\Delta: x \to x \times xΔ:x→x×x, and then in (Cop,×,1)(\mathsf{C}^{\rm op}, \times, 1)(Cop,×,1) this becomes a morphism from x×xx \times xx×x to xxx which, you can show, is an associative multiplication - the μ\muμ you want.
It's fun to show that this multiplication really is associative.

So I guess in a general monoidal category, (C,⊗,I)(C,\otimes,I)(C,⊗,I), the unit is not necessarily terminal (good to know!), but in a cartesian category, the unit is always terminal, but you could have 0=1 (also good to know) :thinking:
(my brain hurts, but in a good way :sweat_smile:)

Yes, and don't forget that in the category with just one object the initial object is also terminal, products are also coproducts, etc. It's a good counterexample to keep in mind in case you think things need to be different.
